html:
Underneath Georgetown's street, a chance to restore history

GM happened to notice this weekend that a couple small patches of asphalt on 29th st. have eroded away to reveal the wonderful cobblestones that lie beneath (alright, if you must be a stickler, they’re really called Belgian blocks or setts, but let’s not get hung up on that).

Nice Guy Burns Debuts Nice Guy Johnny at Newseum

Actor, writer, director Ed Burns moved graciously amongst guests that included The News Hour's Judy Woodruff and Sen. Kristen Gillibrand (D-NY) at the Newseum celebrating independent film and television hosted by Comcast & Tribeca Enterprises.

Blue Crush

The architecturally exquisite space now housing the new strength training/yoga center Stroga in Adams Morgan was the site of the first annual Chris4Life colon cancer Blue Crush benefit Tuesday. Hosted by Philippa P.B.

va-k-shun

------------------------------------------------

Tree Carnage Around Georgetown

At least two large trees snapped apart during yesterdays heavy storms. In both cases, heavy branches fell onto parked cars, but only one car appeared significantly damaged.

Washington Post, New York Times be warned: AU Prof develops bloggers, spin-meisters, journo-lists

You might be fooled by American University Professor Pallavi Kumar's broad smile, friendly tone, and easy conversationality -- but be warned. Writers, would-be journalists, bloggers and spin-meisters have a new weapon.

Zach Bartholomew Trio Plays at Martin's

Halfway up the coast from hometown Tallahassee on their "Get Out of Town" tour, Zach Bartholomew, Brandon Robertson and Miles Bozeman performed in Washington D.C. for the first time Monday night at Billy Martin's Tavern in Georgetown.

Home affordability at best level in 10 years

Thanks in part to interest rates continuing at all-time lows, home affordability in the U.S. remains near the most attractive levels in 10 years.

Hollywood on the Potomac: Washingtonian's Best of Washington Among the Best

Last night's Best of Washington party at the National Building Museum attracted 1,500 Washingtonians, turning out in force to graze among restaurant creations and support the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society.

Hollywood on the Potomac: The Ken and Barbie Show at L2

L2 was saturated with Kens and Barbies on Friday night. Here are some fun facts courtesy of Mattel: Barbie has had more than 80 careers -- everything from a rock star to a paleontologist to a presidential candidate.

Georgetowners Weigh in on Mayoral Election

Santé! The Belgian Embassy Beer Dinner

Belgian Ambassador and Mrs. Jan Matthysen weren't the only ones touting Belgian beer at a dinner in their residence.

Chefs Move to Schools

Ellen Kassoff Gray remembers marching around the playground of Murch Elementary School. She was in second grade and the song the class was singing went somewhat like this: “March is the time farmers will start to bring out their tractors….it’s spring time again…”

Ein Builds Kastles in D.C. Field of Dreams

The heavens let loose an evening downpour, turning avenues into parking lots, slamming the breaks on rushour. "Mark is...uhh, running a little late," says a Ray-ban wearing Kastles official, looking at her Blackberry, then at her phone. "He's stuck in Georgetown traffic."

Last Call: John Morrell at Addison/Ripley Fine Art

Boy’s death spurs debate over traffic safety

The boy who was struck by a woman driving her car near the intersection of Wisconsin and 33rd St. died Tuesday. This has lead at least one news source to question whether that intersection is safe without traffic lights or stop signs.

Liberté, Egalité, Fraternité!

D.C. celebrated all things French on Wednesday night as revelers gathered at Central Michel Richard for the restaurant's third annual Bastille day celebration.

District Design - Barcelona & Madrid

New York, LA, Paris – Sure, everyone knows these cities are the “it” destinations for design and fashion. But there are fabulous finds in any city if you’re a chic and savvy girl (or guy) who knows how and where to look.

Georgetown Cupcakes Celebrate Sweet TV Success at Ritz

Georgetown Cupcake hosted a preview party at the Ritz-Carlton Georgetown, where the store's founders -- now reality TV stars -- Sophie LaMontagne and Katherine Kallinis celebrated their new TLC network show, "DC Cupcakes." The show debuts this Friday at 10 p.m.

Crime Ticks Down for the Second Quarter

Crime in Georgetown continued to stay low for the second quarter of this year versus last year, although it was up significantly from the first quarter’s sharp decline.

Viva España! Muy Caliente are the Victors

DC Examiner's Tara Palmeri to NY Post's Page Six

Sassy Yeas & Nays columnist Tara Palmeri didn't go unnoticed by Richard Johnson of The New York Post's Page Six after a kerfuffle with Sean Penn at a Haiti Benefit in D.C. She made news and lands in New York next week.

TBD.com has fun before launch of frontal challenge to Post

Designer DNA - part II

I continue to pull images and look for inspiration during my quest for self-awareness and decorative zen. I’m like an aesthetic Dali Lama these days. Below are a dozen faves – both owned and coveted – that tell me more about who I am in style and spirit. Ohmmmm.

"Kirk McEwen & Mike O'Meara Show” Premieres on 105-9 The EDGE

A new morning radio show in D.C. premiered today on 105-9 The EDGE which will bring classic rock to Washingtonian’s commutes. At the inaugural "Kirk McEwen & Mike O'Meara Show” show this morning, the EDGE studio was filled with TV cameras and local celebrities.

Rocking before Rolling

A great deal of the success in selling a property is in the preparation for sale. If one's eye is on "the sale" rather than the myriad details of preparation, one is likely to overlook necessary details and wind up without a sale, or at a price lower than desired.

Hollywood on the Potomac: Chelsea's Wedding

Jobs and Georgetown Housing

Thankfully we live in one of the most stable parts of the world with regard to jobs. That is one of the things which has kept us moving forward in the housing market in general. But the national drag on real estate has been significant as a result of job losses.

Designer DNA

At Huntley & Co. when a new project begins, the first thing I do is develop a concept. I pour over books, magazines, websites and my own archives to find inspiring and expressive images. Ones that will represent the client’s sense of style and capture the spirit of the proposed interior.
